Lessons From the Asia Crisis

“If You Allow Capitalism to Work, It Does”

Since 1998 we have maintained the U.S. had the potential of being the “Asia crisis writ large”. In both cases the bubble was caused by overcapacity financed with “cheap” capital, overvalued markets encouraged by accommodating central bankers and overpriced currencies driven by massive foreign direct and portfolio investment.

Emerging Thoughts: Policy Paralysis in India

India is grinding to a halt. Well, not all of India, but an important part of it which depends on government policy action. The reason is the exposure of corruption and scandals associated with government officials taking bribes. 
Corruption has been endemic in India since the time of independence in 1947 (and maybe well before that as well). What’s different this time is that the media have been exposing this corruption and on the back of these revelations important people (more specifically senior politicians and billionaires) are being put in jail and are being kept there, with judges refusing to grant them bail. 
In the past, these same people would give and take bribes with impunity, secure in the knowledge that they were above scrutiny and prosecution and even if they were sent to jail, could live a 5 star luxury lifestyle while there, with home cooked meals, internet access, personal butlers and afternoon tea with the wardens. In the harsh light of intense media scrutiny, all that has changed. Things have got so bad that there’s anecdotal evidence that industrialists are refusing to give bribes to politicians on the grounds that the politicians are not acting despite being bribed!!! 
This is not the fear of an innocent person being unfairly accused, but of a guilty person being afraid being exposed. Accusing a politician of corruption in India is akin to handing out speeding tickets at the Indy 500*. 
Now this may sound like a very positive change, and in fact, in the long run, it probably is. However, in the short run, it has had a chilling effect on all aspects of government action – no action is being taken on new projects, projects that have been approved are not being funded and even works in progress (like road construction) have halted as funds are not being disbursed. 
I have often made the argument that India succeeds if the government gets out of the way. However, India has a high need for government action in the arena of infrastructure, supply chains etc. and there’s evidence that bottlenecks in the economy are creating a serious impediment to fast growth without inflationary pressure. In fact the Reserve Bank is so worried that it raised rates 50bps today and in effect told the government to get off its butt and deal with the bottlenecks -
 “It is important to recognize that in the absence of appropriate actions for addressing supply bottlenecks, especially in food and infrastructure, questions about the ability of the economy to sustain the current growth rate without significant inflationary pressures come to the fore. The economy's ability to grow rapidly for any length of time without provoking inflation is dependent on implementing policies, with corresponding resource allocations, which will allow the supply of various products and services to keep pace with demand.”

Why we got Russia wrong

In 1993, I joined GMO to launch our Emerging Markets strategy, known as the GMO Emerging Markets Fund (EMF).

I have always been quick to quote Sir John Templeton, “The four most dangerous words in the English language are – This Time it’s Different”. And it almost never is. Except now. It is almost certainly different this time and that’s why we got it wrong.

We manage EMF with a focus on the top down – our view is (and has been for the entire 28 years period) that in emerging markets getting the country right is the most important thing. As a result, we allocate 60-70% of our risk units to picking countries and sectors.

We do this in a primarily quantitative fashion – using objective data to evaluate the attractiveness of every country along multiple dimensions – value, macroeconomics, ESG, momentum and quality, with value being overwhelmingly the most important.

In addition to the quantitative models, I have always believed that one cannot rely completely on purely quantitative measures in emerging markets and so we have a fundamental team to help us determine if there are other factors that cannot be quantified (war, elections, natural disasters, poor policy making, etc) that should lead us to override the quantitative models. We override very rarely and the hurdle to override is high. Since we so rarely override the models, we have tracked our record of overrides and it has been quite successful. As I like to say, the point of overriding is not to make the heroic bet, but to avoid the big mistake. Obviously not true in this circumstance.

This strategy has worked well for us over the last 28 years. Our record shows that we have consistently added value through country selection and remains our biggest differentiator and competitive advantage relative to other emerging strategies.

With that as background, let’s look at what happened over the past week and evaluate the decisions we made that led to us being hugely overweight Russia with a 14% overweight going into the crisis.

Russia scored as extremely attractive on value, positive on macroeconomics, negative on quality and ESG and neutral on momentum [BINU FIX THIS].
Given the attractiveness on value and macroeconomics, we ended up with an extremely positive score overall which would lead our portfolio construction process to determine a maximum overweight position (15% above benchmark). Over the past 10 years, we have had a large overweight in Russia on numerous occasions and it has worked well for us and so this was not an unusual situation.

So then the question became – in the face of the threats that Putin had started to make, did we override the model and take down our overweight or even get out of Russia altogether?

Alas, we did not.
What was our thinking behind this?

We believed that while there was a strong threat and posturing from Putin, we did not think he would launch an all out assault on the entire country, but even if he attacked, he would limit himself to the Donbas region and take the parts of it that he did not already control. In that circumstance, we felt that the West would make a lot of noise like in 2014, but ultimately we would return to business as usual. In my mind I put a 50% probability that nothing would happen, 45% probability that he would take Donbas and a 5% probability that he would go all in. We were clearly wrong in our assessment of potential outcomes.

An Unﬁnished Tale of Two Bubbles   What’s the common theme linking Cisco and Nvidia?   They’re both equipment suppliers to a new technology that’s going to change the world. And right now, like in 1998, everybody with half a brain can see that these new technologies are going to be huge. But, unfortunately, there are very few ways to play that glorious future that’s in the near future.  We all know the story of Levi Strauss & Co. during the California Gold Rush – the equipment suppliers that made money in that bubble.  And so we see Cisco and Nvidia today in a similar vein.   But once the technology starts to be used to actually change the world, other companies are major beneﬁciaries (like Amazon, Google etc.) and the equipment suppliers are correctly seen as commodity producers with low margins as competition seeps in.  And so it is today. Here’s a chart of Cisco vs Nvidia starting 18 months before the top of the tech bubble on a similar time and return scale.

Are we now at the top for Nvidia? That’s unknowable.  As my colleague Jeremey Grantham likes to say, trying to ﬁgure out the top of a bubble is like charting the path of a feather in a hurricane. You have no idea as to how far or how high it will go. There is only one thing you know with certainty. It will hit the ground.  And so it was with Cisco…   If you bought it at the top - almost 25 years later, you’re still losing money.  
  So will Nvidia follow suit? Inevitably.  What I predict is that sometime in the next 12 moths, we will see the peak. And you’re a fool if you think you can time that event exactly.  My advice is to sell 1/12th of your Nvidia holding now and another 1/12th every month for the next 12 months irrespective of what the stock does. That way, if I’m right that the top will be in the next 12 months, you will have got out near the top. And save yourself a bunch of sleepless nights.

The Opportunity
We have been managing money in emerging markets for nearly 18 years and it has been fascinating to see changes 
in not only where opportunities to make money could be found, but also in how the nature of those opportunities has evolved.   Back in the 1990s, companies that did best were those that were export oriented, as outsourcing became an established phenomenon.   During the 2000s, as commodity prices rose steeply, it was the commodity producers that did extremely well.   Now, with economics and demographics moving away from developed markets, we believe we are in the early stages of another major shift, toward companies that serve domestic demand within emerging markets. 
 In the past, emerging markets were too small and illiquid to allow investors to commit substantial assets to narrow 
strategies, but in recent years, emerging markets have increased in size and liquidity to the extent that it now makes little sense to view them as a monolithic asset class.   With an investable market cap of $4 trillion and daily trading volume of around $40 billion, emerging markets are rapidly approaching the size and liquidity of developed markets.
 While there are many ways to segment emerging markets – by region, big cap vs.  small cap, value vs.  growth – we 
believe a more appropriate segmentation is to think about companies based on the ultimate customers they serve.   Within this view, we see businesses as belonging to one of three distinct groups: exporters, global commodity producers, and those that serve domestic demand in the form of consumption and infrastructure. 
 In recent years, there has been much talk about the coupling/decoupling of emerging markets vis-à-vis the developed 
world.   We ﬁ nd this either/or characterization misses the mark when, in fact, the reality is far more complicated.  
 Perhaps a better way to think about growth in emerging markets is to characterize it as having two components: correlated growth , which is driven by links with the developed world, and uncorrelated growth , which depends more 
on the internal dynamics and demographics of the emerging markets themselves. 
 From this viewpoint, exporters and global commodity producers largely represent correlated growth , while domestic 
demand mostly represents uncorrelated growth .   Obviously, in a globalized world, there is a large overlap between 
these two, with both positive and negative feedback loops. Shooting the Messenger?

On July 2, the 100-year badla system will give away to a T+ 5 compulsory rolling settlement system. While this change is ostensibly geared to creating a more transparent system, the timing of the move reflects paranoia on the part of the authorities and will only exacerbate the bear market. The main casualty has been and will continue to be liquidity!

A liquid stock market enables capital to get allocated quickly and efficiently, benefiting investors, companies and governments.  Today, investors pay significant premiums for liquidity in all equity markets. In an increasingly competitive world for investment dollars, one of the few advantages Indian markets had was liquidity and depth.  Unlike other emerging markets where only a handful of stocks are liquid, India boasted tens of stocks that traded over $100 million a day each; greatly increasing it’s attractiveness to large investors.

Why does liquidity matter? There are several companies in emerging markets that are more profitable, but more undervalued on any metric when compared to Indian companies. Take an example of Thai Union Frozen - it’s the equivalent of Infosys in the global shrimp business with revenues of $800 million (twice that of Infosys) and profits of $50 million. It has a return on equity of 20% and earnings growth of 15-20% annually. Yet it has a market value of less than $300 million as compared to $8 billion for Infosys. Why is so undervalued? The shrimp business is certainly less sexy than software, but at the end of the day they are both cyclical commodity businesses. The main reason for the difference in value is liquidity as it trades a measly $50,000 to $100,000 a day versus $200 -300 million for Infosys. While it is easy to dismiss Thailand today, lets not forget that in 1994 the market traded over $1 billion a day (when India traded $20-30 million a day).

Implicit in today’s Indian market multiples is a premium for liquidity. As liquidity reduces, it can easily set up a vicious circle leading to valuations for software leaders to drop to 10 to 15 times (or less) earnings. We have already seen this happen with the second and third tier software companies. This effectively increases the cost of capital impacting their global competitiveness. The dream that software exports will reach $80 billion by 2008 will remain just that.

It's easy to want to find scapegoats for a vicious bear market. Bursting the global tech bubble of 1998-2000 caused pain everywhere, not just in India. The high liquidity associated with this bubble may now appear speculative and harmful but lets not forget the benefits that India enjoyed from it. Liquidity enabled a lot of companies to raise cheap capital and improve balance sheets. Today, in the technology downturn this capital will help them survive. The boom in stock prices created unprecedented media publicity for the Indian software story. It resulted in India being on the investment horizon of a lot of institutions that earlier avoided it.

To Indian regulators, futures and options may seem to be the panacea to cure the evils of badla (of which there are undoubtedly many). However, they have not been successful in any emerging market we know of. The biggest investors in most emerging markets are foreign and domestic mutual funds - they are severely constrained in the use of such derivative instruments. In nascent capital markets, small domestic investors don’t really understand the intricacies of such instruments and end up being losers. Who then will use these derivatives? Ketan Parikh?

SEBI has recently released the list of companies which will have options traded.  Some companies that were trading more than $300 million a day have been excluded, presumably on the ground that they were speculative favourites. Lets not forget that speculation and investment are two sides of the same coin. It's impossible to have one without the other. It should not be the role of the market regulator to decide which stocks should have options (and therefore affect capital allocation) - let the market decide that. If there are then abuses of market manipulation, they should use the existing laws on the books to deal with them.

It’s easy to dismiss successful homegrown systems and go in for fancy American toys. However, non-market solutions to a market-based problem are inevitably a recipe for disaster. Lets not shoot the messenger!
